PRIAM US Serial Publication of the Centre for Entomological Studies Ankara Volume 17 Part 3 17 12 2018 ISSN 1015-8243 ►Uighurs are an ancient civilization in the world; indestructible even under inhuman pressures^ http://zoobank.org/References/FE4DF8Bl-133B-40E0-B79D-739F44B8ElD3 Contributions to the fauna and taxonomy on some Heterocera of Uighur Ili (Lepidoptera) Muhabbet Kemal 1 Ahmet Omer Ko^ak Abstract: Contributions to the fauna and taxonomy on some Heterocera of Uighur Ili (Lepidoptera). Priamus 17 (3): 210-318, 2 appendices, 63 figs., 36 maps. In this paper, 50 species of 10 families are mentioned. Various problems of some taxa are discussed. A new subspecies of Arctia caja is described. Adult moth, genitalia and tympanal organ of some species are illustrated. Totally 17 species are reported here from the Uighur Ili for the first time. For diagnostic purpose, 12 male genitalia, 6 female genitalia are illustrated. Separately, tympanal organs of 7 species are also illustrated. Pictorial observations are also given. Informative lists of Heterocera of Kirazdere (Amasya, N Turkey), Heterocera of Uighur Ili, and 36 maps are added. Key words: Arctiidae, Coleophoridae, Geometridae, Lymantriidae, Noctuidae, Notodontidae, Pyralidae, Saturniidae, Scythridae, Tortricidae, Lepidoptera , Uighur Ili, fauna, genitalia, tympanal organ, maps. A small collection of the Heterocera from the Ili Region 2 3 between Ghulja and Tokuztara, North of Teklimakan Desert (Uighur Ili). Materials were collected by the authors in 2005 from following localities: Kondeleng (Ron), Kichikku§tay (Kty), Mongolkure (Mkii), Urumchi (Um). In 2011, the first author observed several species in the Ili Region (Ghulja [Ru], Akuzen [Aku] North of Ghulja (Fig.i)s, Rimes [Run], Narat [Nra] (Fig.2), and Siiydong [Sjd]). The aim of the authors with this short paper is to share their scientific opinions about the species listed below, and evaluate them especially from the faunistical standpoint. Totally 50 species of 10 moth families are given and discussed. Arctia caja ssp. roshengul (ssp.n.) is proposed here as new subspecies. For the purpose of identifications of the species, 12 male genitalia, 6 female genitalia, as well as 7 tympanal organs are prepared and illustrated. Following species are reported here from Uighur Ili for the first time: Manulea complana, Phragmatobia fuliginosa paghmani, Horisme vitalbata, Ligdia coctata, Scopula decorata, Scotopteryx chenopodiata, Lymantria dispar, Amphipyra tragopoginis, Anaplectoides prasina, Athetis lepigone, Catocala neonympha, Eublemma purpurinum, Lacanobia thalassina, Lygephila craccae, Xestia baja bajula, Oncocera semirubella, Ostrinia nubilalis. Tympanal organ of Gnophopsodos stemmataria is illustrated here for the first time. Female genitalia of Cryphia rueckbeili is also illustrated here for the first time. List of the Heterocera species of Uighur Ili is also updated in Appendix II (see also Remal & Rogak, 2007a-b). All the images used in this paper are preserved in the Cesa archive, and the material in the Collection of the Cesa. Nomenclaturally unavailable names are marked with # (Uninominal names or nomina nuda). The symbol * denotes that the mtCOI DNA of the species will be examined separately. 1 Dr Muhabbet Kemal - Van Yiiziincii Yil University, Faculty of Science, Dept, of Biology, Campus, Van / Turkey, e-mails: muhabbet kemal(Syahoo,com.tr Prof. em. Dr Ahmet Omer Kogak, c/o Yiiziincii Yil University, Faculty of Science, Dept, of Biology, e-mail: cesa tr( 5 )yahoo.com.tr 2 “Ili” means [l] “vatan” in Uighur and Turkish languages, [2] name of the main river in this region, up to Kaptschagai (Alma-Ata, W. Kazachstan), [3] name of the region. This definition was used by various authors in the past (Wagner, 1913; Boursin, 1953, etc). 3 Gold mine excavations at North of Akuzen, disturb severely the ecosystems of the valley. Range (as codes): pt es fr Co it ie gb be nl lu de ch at pl cz sk hu ro yu bg gr tr dk no se fi ee lv LT MD UA Cm BY GG Cc AZ Nv AM KG Ssn CN Hph Ui Kml Tek Kty KK TJ Pm Fe UZ AF PK Ch Snm IN Up Alh Khs IR Elb Mz At MN RU Sb Kmt Am Vv To Mgd Ya Sj Ir Irk Ur Kr KP KR JP Clu Hkk CA US Als Ut Jn Lng Lw 05 08 14 25 32 36 58 60 6165 75 Remarks: An Holarctic species and morphologically its taxonomical problems has not been solved yet. It is represented by 12 subspecies in Eurasia, apart from the nominate one (Dubatolov,20io). These are as follows; kamtschadalis Draudt,i93i (Russia: Kamtschatka), martinhoneyi Dubatolov & Gurko,2005 (Kashmir; originally described as species, later treated as a subspecies (Dubatolov,2010)), mazandarana Dubatolov & Zahiri,2005 (Northern Iran), olschwangi Dubatolov,1990 (Polar Russia, Alaska; later treated as distinct species (Dubatolov & Philip,2013)), orientalis Moore,1878 (NW India), ossetica Dubatolov,1996 (North Caucasus), pamiroalaica Stshetkin,i982 (Alai-Pamirs in Tadjikistan and Afghanistan), phaeosoma Butler,1877 (from Russia Primorye to Japan), sajana O.Bang-Haas,i927 (Russia, East Sajan, Yakutia; Mongolia), tschiliensis Draudt,i93i (Russia Amur basin to China Hebei), tshimgana Sheljuzhko,i935 (Uzbekistan: Tshimgan), wiskotti Staudinger,i879 (Turkey, NWIran). Nominate subspecies is found in Europe, and some northern parts of asiatic Russia (Dubatolov, 1996, 2010; Dubatolov & Philip, 2013). Among them, tschiliensis, kamtschadalis and wiskotti are well illustrated in Seitz’s Supplement volume pl.7 (Draudt,i93i). The name martihoneyi, after comparing morphologically by Dubatolov & Gurko (2005) with the type of orientalis, was proposed as a species. Later, Dubatolov (2010) placed it as a subspecies of caja Linnaeus. Sheljuzhko (1935) described tshimgana from Uzbekistan. Other central asiatic subspecies, like pamiroalaica, sajana, phaeosoma, as well as ossetica, wiskotti, are well illustrated by Dubatolov online 4 . After checking all the subspecies, including the nominate one mentioned above, the authors came to the conclusion that in Uighur Ili an undescribed subspecies exists. Description of this subspecies is given below: * Arctia (s.str.) caja ssp. roshengul (ssp.n.) (Fig. 3) http://zoobank.org/NomenclaturalActs/ 94 F 51 C 48 - 968 A- 42 A 4 -A 6 EC- 69290 CC 302 BC Description: Holotype ($): Forewing: 34mm, wingspan: 69mm. Head and thorax with long cinnamon-coloured hairs. Collar red. Abdomen with bright red, long hairs; dorsally black-spotted. Upperside of forewing ground colour dark creamy, all spots are cinnamon- coloured. Costa with five broad bands, among them 2-4 more or less anastomosed with the asymmetrical blotch in the midst of posterior margin. On outer margin, three large, almost triangular shaped blotches well developed and fused with each other. Subanal blotch divided into two. Basal area with irregular shaped small spots. Hind wing upperside with four black blotches, two round, two irregular shaped, with hardly visible indigo-blue centre. A small irregular shaped black discal spot also well developed. Underside of the wings, patterns and colourations similar to those of upperside but paler in some parts. Diagnosis: With the colourations and patterns of the wings, this taxon is different from all known subpecies of Arctia caja in Central Asia. Material studied: 1$ (Holotype), Uighur Ili, Ili Region, Tekes, Kichikku§tay 1800m, 10.vii.2005, M.Kemal & A. Kogak leg. (in coll. Cesa) Etymology: The name of this subspecies is dedicated to Roshengul Shawket (1928-1945). Roshengul is born in 1928 to a wealthy and educated family in Ghulja city of East Turkestan. Her father was a teacher. Due to his intervention with the two Kuomintang soldiers, who molesting high school girls in the middle of the street, he was arrested, then executed. A year later, Roshengiil’s mother died. Roshengul lived with servants working at her home for a while. 4 http://szmn.eco.nsc.ru/Lepidop/images/Arctia caia.htm Some Heterocera of Uighur Ili ... 211 Volume 17 (3) Priamus ISSN 1015-8243 Centre for Entomological Studies Ankara 17 12 2018 Like many European women who sacrificed their lives for their homeland during the Second World War, Uyghur women also showed incredible heroism in the war of independence of East Turkistan, which started in 1944. One of those heroic women was the 16-year-old Roshengiil. She left all her possessions to the servants and joined the army as soldier. She served as a nurse in the army. On September 5, 1945, soldiers injured in the battle near the city of Jing were in urgent need of water. There was a creek running about 150 meters away from the point where the soldiers were. Roshengiil wanted to bring to the soldiers in distress. However, the commander did not want to allow this to be dangerous. Because, their position was under surveillance by Kuomintang soldiers. But Roshengiil insisted. On the edge of the creek, where she went to get water, Roshengiil was martyred by the concealed Kuomintang soldiers. She was only 17 years old (Kemal Yunusoglu, 2015). Denis and Schiffermiiller (1775: 114) proposed with the binominal name, “Geometra adustata”, but without morphological description. According to the current ICZN Rules, such names cannot be used as valid of the species. Later, Fabricius (1787: 205) used this name as “ Phalaena adustata” with full descriptions. Hereby, the Fabricius’s name became the valid name for the species, at the same time type-species of the genus Ligdia Guenee (see also Kogak, 1982- 1987; Kogak & Kemal, 2015). Some Heterocera of Uighur Ili... 214 Volume 17 (3) Priamus ISSN 1015-8243 Centre for Entomological Studies Ankara 17 12 2018 Differences especially on the shape of valva of the male genitalia may be important in discriminating the european and Bolu population in asiatic Turkey (Fig. 20). [2] . Rogenhofer (1873) described a new species, “Abraxas lassulata” from Giilek (Bulgar Mts.) in the Taurus Mountain Range (South Turkey). This is perhaps the valid name of the species, inhabiting in asiatic Turkey. But, it is currently needed faunistical investigations in Turkey. There are also some taxonomical problems with lassulata, namely; although it was described originally as bona species, Wehrli (1934: 34) considered it as a subspecies of Ligdia coctata Gn., while Skou & Sihvonen (2015) treated it temporarily under Ligdia adustata. [3] . Staudinger (1879: 443) proposed a geographical variation of adustata, as “inspersata” from “Kerasdere”. This name was described from Kirazdere (now suburb of Amasya city, North of Turkey), but the name of the collecting locality misspelled by Staudinger as “Kerasdere”. He collected many species from Kerasdere during his stay in Amasya in 1875. In his paper on page 206, he explained the meaning of his “Kerasdere” as follows: “... Ich komme nun zu der fur uns wohl am Ergiebigsten Lokalitat, zu dem Kerasdere (Keras - Kirsche, Dere - Thai)...”. Later, Staudinger (1881: 79) considered his name inspersata as junior synonym of lassulata. [4] . Whalley (1970: 49) took changing the spelling a step further 5 , namely he proposed a generic name in the Phycitinae, by changing “Kerasdere” into “Keradere”. He also indicated the locality as “Turkey: Keradere”. Thus the original name Kirazdere of Amasya changed into “Kerasdere”, later “Keradere” in the lepidopterological literature. [5] . Finally, Skou & Sihvonen (2015: 52) published their opinions about the “Kerasdere” and its geographical location. According to them, “Kerasdere” must be [Karadere], and located in [Mugla Province], SW Turkey. [6] . Mugla Province is around 800km SW of Amasya Province in Turkey. Staudinger was many times around “Kerasdere” in Amasya and collected numerous species from there [see Appendix I], but he never visited Mugla Province. He wrote about his travel to Amasya and the excursions around this city in detail. If the wrongs had been accepted, the world, we live in today, would be very different. We believe that.
